title: quirky invention pictures see through barbers apron balcony paddling pool
story: From a see-through barbers apron, to a family who turned their balcony into a paddling pool, the quirky creations take thinking-outside-the-box to a whole new level.Taken from all corners of the globe, the snaps have been shared on Bored Panda.The ideas range from simple life hacks, such as a boy who used a bunch of bananas as a stand for his phone so he could watch films during a flight, to more elaborate inventions.One picture shows a kid lounging in a paddling pool made from covering a balcony with plastic sheeting and filling it with water.In another shot a man has come up with a wacky, albeit unhygienic, way to tuck into his dinner while watching television - by using a toilet seat as a tray.Meanwhile, others got creative in the kitchen, with one inventor turning a toaster horizontal to allow him to cook cheese on toast.In a separate instance a savvy cook uses a plastic bottle as a shield from splashing oil while frying.And, in other invention news, a television reporter proves a selfie stick will do the trick in the absence of a cameraman.Here are some of the home-made gadgets that will get your creative juices flowing.

title: health and safety mum remove children paddling pool
story: Paige Ball, 24, was told that the 10ft blue plastic pool outside her block of flats in Plymouth, Devon, needs to go because it is a health risk.Plymouth Community Homes told her to remove the pool “as a matter of urgency” because of health and safety concerns.They sent a letter to residents which said: “Due to health and safety concerns and public liability insurance issues I must ask you to remove the swimming pool as a matter of urgency.If not, Plymouth Community Homes will have no option but to organise for the removal of the swimming pool and the cost will be charged to the owner of the pool.Thank you in advance for your co-operation in this matter.Paige, who has two youngsters aged three and four, said: Its unfair for them to ruin summer for our children.The pool is my cousin’s but I often have my own pool up too.I offered to buy a cover for the top of the pool to make it safer, but we have been told this still would not be allowed.Theres plenty of space, I just dont understand it. Its our children who will miss out.I just think its wrong really. Its not fair for people on a budget that want to take their kids out.Its better for them to be safe where we can watch them than running in the road.We only leave the pool up for no more than three days, so it doesnt waste the water, and then we pack it away again.My kids love it and PCH are ruining it for them.Fran Sandercock, a senior housing officer at Plymouth Community Homes, said We take the safety of our residents extremely seriously.We dont want to spoil anyones summer fun but we also dont want to see children get injured so have asked that the pool is removed.Were always happy to speak to residents about alternative types of childrens play and will happily meet them to discuss any options they may put forward.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: how cornish pasties and scotch whisky could end up sinking post brexit trade deal with us
story: Trade Secretary Liam Fox has written to David Davis demanding him to stand up to Brussels and diverge from the EUs protected status food so we can do a deal with America after Brexit.The UK has 83 protected food and drinks, which means that food made outside of that area cant be marketed in the same way.Across Europe there are 3,300 other types of protected goods - such as French champagne, Greek feta, or Parma Ham - all of which the US produces its own versions of.Brussels boss Michel Barnier says the issue is non negotiable and we MUST recognise the special status of all the foods after we leave before we start talking about a trade deal.But Dr Fox has said we have to be able to go it alone and diverge from the bloc after warnings from Donald Trumps ally Paul Ryan, the  reported.The regulations also protect other traditional foods including Stornoway black pudding, Fenland celery, Cumberland sausages and Whitstable oysters.During a recent visit to the US he was told by the senior Republican and Speaker of the House of Representatives that the UK must be able to diverge from the EU protected status to secure a deal.Earlier this year Danish exporters were caught illegally selling cheese as feta overseas - in a long-running dairy battle.It can only be labelled as such if its made in Greece using sheep milk.But the Danes use cow milk and its far less crumbly.Theresa May has said she hoped to sign a speedy deal with the US as soon as we leave the bloc.But any deal with the EU could have an effect on negotiations with the Americans.A Government spokesman said: Leaving the EU gives us a golden opportunity to secure ambitious free-trade deals that are in the mutual interests of the countries involved while supporting farmers and producers to grow and sell more great British food.We will ensure consumers continue to have a range of high-quality food products. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: israeli airline el al blasted female passengers move orthodox jews refused sit next to them
story: The El Al flight was delayed for more than an hour as new seats were found for the pair.But when crew on the New York to Tel Aviv flight tried to reason with the men, they refused to speak to them - because they too were female.A man who claims he was a passenger, Khen Rotem, took to Facebook to report the events as they unfolded.In one post, reported by the Times of Israel, he wrote: “All the men in the crew, except for the captain, are now only dealing with this instead of preparing for take-off and serving the passengers.”He added that eventually an elderly American and young Israeli switched seats allowing the plane to take-off.Khen described one of the men as “particularly devout” and explained how he got on the plane with his eyes closed and kept them shut for the duration of the flight.In a statement given to Times of Israel, El Al apologised for the “inconvenience” to passengers.It said: Any discrimination against passengers is absolutely forbidden. El Al flight attendants do all they can in order to provide service to a wide variety of passengers with different and diverse requests and try to assist to the best of their ability.”This week’s disturbance follows a similar incident last year when a case of discrimination was filed against the airline by a woman who had also been shifted from her designated seat for the same reason.In that instance, Israel’s Supreme Court ruled that asking a passenger to move seat based on gender is a form of discrimination.

title: labours plans for the economy could cost every brit 6k and even ruin our pubs and holidays
story: David Lidington slammed Labours promise to stop private firms getting involved in public services.And he suggested it could take us back to the days when the state ran pubs, golf courses and travel agents - providing dreary service at sky-high prices.Jeremy Corbyn has pledged to scrap nearly all outsourcing in the wake of the collapse of Carillion - claiming the scandal shows paying companies to run public services is a waste of money.But Mr Lidington today hit back, warning that taxpayers would face much higher bills and worse services.The Cabinet Office minister - who is the PMs de facto deputy - told the Reform think-tank: You can have good and bad in private and public cases.What matters is that the service works for people who use it, while at the same time providing value-for-money for the taxpayers.In a dig at Labour, he added: There are some who think the Government must do it all.Mr Lidington said ending outsourcing would bring about the biggest wave of nationalisation since the 1980s.He suggested the plans would also see a repeat of the days when the state owned the Gleneagles golf course, Thomas Cook and all the pubs in Carlisle, before starting to sell them off in the 70s.And he estimated the overall cost in increased taxes to be around £6,000 per household.Mr Lidington insisted the economies of scale and specialist skills which outsourcing allows mean public services can be provided cheaper than by the Government.Labours policy, introduced after Carillion went into liquidation, is to ban all outsourcing except when its absolutely necessary.The party would force councils and Government departments to bid against private firms for services contracts, and only allow companies to take over projects which are shown to be failing.Labour also wants to stop civil servants from choosing a bid just because its the cheapest for the taxpayer.Mr Corbyn accuses outsourcing firms such as Carillion of fleecing the state by making profit from public service contracts.

title: atlantas childish gambino aka donald glover to headline o2 arena
story: It is expected to be the Atlanta star's largest UK performance to date, months after he won a lead actor Emmy for his comedy series.Special guest R&B singer H.E.R. - whose real name is Gabriella "Gabi" Wilson - will also perform.The show will be the second UK appearance for the multi-talented American artist, who headlines at Gunnersbury Park's Lovebox Festival in July.   His political single, This Is America, which sparked debate about gun violence in the US, reached number 6 in the UK charts earlier this year.Glover has previously hinted that he may soon kill-off his Gambino alter ego, saying at the Grammy's in January: "I'm making another project right now. But I like endings, I think they're important to progress."I think if a lot of things had death clauses in them we wouldn't have a lot of problems in the world, to be honest. I think endings are good because they force things to get better."Tickets for Childish Gambino's 02 concert go on sale at 9am on 29 June.

title: europes migration triage has left a hangover that requires urgent reform in two key areas
story: The current situation in terms of migrant arrivals is not actually that bad it's certainly well down on the 2015 peak.However the EU's failure to address the flow back then shifted politics in several key countries, which is now having consequences.The numerous 'crunch' migration summits in 2015 were, on reflection, only about triage. They didn't address the problems or find solutions.:: EU leaders hold 'frank and open' talks at emergency migration summitEurope's migration policy doesn't work - the asylum burden remains on frontier countries like Italy and Greece to take the strain. And the returns policy doesn't work - failed asylum seekers (economic migrants) are not being returned home - either because their home country won't take them or because the EU country they are in fails to deport them often it's both.So they are left to live in an unpleasant illegal limbo.I am in touch with a number of people who I met through the years as I've reported on migration.They have repeatedly been rejected for asylum and yet they are still here, trying again. The 'populist' and anti-establishment governments who secured power because of the 2015 failures have now politicised the issue and are forcing fundamental change.The paradox being that while the optics are of boatloads still arriving, the figures show that arrivals are a fraction of the number they were.This has caused ructions all over the place: :: Germany:: The Italian 'populists'France and Italy have been lobbing insults at each other over the migrant issue. It's extremely unusual for two such central players in the EU to be at loggerheads.It's a useful demonstration of how the Italian 'populists' roll and it's playbook-Trump stuff.The two men who call the shots in Rome - Matteo Salvini and Luigi Di Miao, the figureheads of the two coalition parties and both now deputy prime ministers - used their vast social media presence to appeal to their support base by denouncing the what they termed the arrogance of the French president (who had dared to suggest that the migration crisis was largely a political row rather than an actual crisis).An aside: Emmanuel Macron cast himself as anti-establishment when he won the presidency just over a year ago (was it only a year ago!?). Now he feels firmly establishment and up against the real mavericks in Italy. :: The migrants on the MedAn ever-growing number of charity rescue ships are stacking up in the Mediterranean with hundreds of rescued migrants on board waiting for a country to accept them.Italy and Malta are essentially playing chicken with them: each country holding the line not accepting the boats until an imminent danger to life forces them to.It's tough, reckless, maybe even illegal but, frankly, it's been effective in forcing the issue onto the table at EU level.Italy has made it clear that it isn't willing to deal with this issue alone.This short film which we made 18 months ago is an attempt to explain what's happening on the Med - nothing's changed since we filmed it. Watch it below. The discussion at EU leader level seems to be going round in circles. They are talking this week about issues they were talking about three years ago: 'hotspots' to process asylum seekers, asylum centers outside the EU, beefing up the external borders.There is no single solution and any discussion must begin with an acceptance that you can't stop migration. It's a fact of our times. It can be managed but not stopped.

title: harry kane praised by gareth southgate as he takes away historic world cup match ball
story: The figures were still behind England's first Group G match against Tunisia, which was watched by a total audience of 21 million - more than the royal wedding.England manager Gareth Southgate, interviewed after the game, said he would choose Kane over any other frontman at the World Cup.Southgate said: "He's started brilliantly."You can dismiss penalties as being easy, but the length of time he had to wait before taking that (first one) and the number of distractions, to then keep focused, start again and refocus tells you a bit about the mental toughness that he's got. "Look, he's there, he's up at the top. We wouldn't swap him for anyone in the tournament in terms of number nines."He went on to say that he is "very confident" that Kane will continue to deliver."You know that when he gets opportunities he's going to bury them. You sit there very confident in his ability to take chances," he said."He's not just a player that stands up front and waits for chances and that's important within the ethic of the team we're trying to create," he added.England won the game with the most goals the team have ever scored in a World Cup finals match.The two penalties and a deflection from Harry Kane, two headers from John Stones and a strike from Jesse Lingard left Panama behind.Kane's hat-trick was the first for England at the World Cup finals since 1986 and it made the captain the first England player to score five goals in the group stage.Many are already tipping him for the tournament's golden boot - the player who scores the most goals in the World Cup finals.Southgate joked that part of the reason he was pleased with Kane's hat-trick was that it meant the captain would be less annoyed when he was taken off the pitch during the game. Some of England's players were able to spend Monday morning relaxing after their emphatic victory, with none of the side which started against Panama in Nizhny Novgorod taking part of the light session back at Zelenogorsk.England player Jesse Lingard was among those revelling in England's victory today, tweeting a picture of his successful strike with a tornado emoji and the hashtag #JLingz.As the team heads towards their Thursday clash with Belgium, Southgate commented: "I've heard talk of, 'Is it better to finish first or second?' I am not sure how we're going to work all of that out really so let's just go and enjoy the game again."It's nice that it's a game where we're not up to our neck in pressure."We have got some decisions to make because the harmony of the group is important to me."   England are now currently level with Belgium on goal difference.

title: sicario 2s benicio del toro its about making the right moral choice
story: In an illegal covert operation, Alejandro is hired by the Americans to kidnap Isabela, a Mexican kingpin's young daughter, to inflame the conflict between cartels.As CIA agent Matt Graver, played by Josh Brolin, tells him: "You're going to help us start a war&#8230 With everyone."But Del Toro explains that this is a character driven film, centred around one man doing the right thing rather than an exploration of drug wars and immigration."The heart of this film for me is really seeing how a heartless hitman could suddenly have a conscience and it's partly though his actions - getting a medicine through what he's doing to an innocent girl - which is a mirror of what happened to his own daughter, and that journey shatters the shell around his heart. "When he's given the order to get rid of the girl he does the right thing - makes the right moral choice."And to up the stakes, Isabela's father is not just any cartel kingpin - he's the man who in the first film murdered Alejandro's entire family.As the film shows illegal immigrants being trafficked over the border by the busload, it's impossible to ignore the parallels with the current US immigration debate.Del Toro says: "To me, the fact that these characters exist in that [border] world makes it a character driven piece&#8230In the film there is often a very fine line between the "good guys" and the "bad guys", with governments, police, soldiers and criminals all fighting their own private battles.Del Toro explains: "I think in a way you start rooting for [Brolin's] character and my character, but they started the fire. It's like - they look like they're putting out the fire, but they were the arsonists."That's what stories do, it plays with that expectation, and I think that's done cleverly by the writer Taylor Sheridan. I can watch a movie like Frankenstein and I root for Frankenstein but is he the monster really? Or is it the doctor?"During the film, the fictional US president is said to change US foreign policy to avoid impeachment.So, does Del Toro think the real US president Donald Trump could face impeachment during his tenure? On that, the actor is diplomatic.

title: turkeys opposition concedes election defeat as erdogan returns as president
story: With only 0.9% of the ballots left to be processed at lunchtime on Monday, Muharrem Ince conceded defeat in Sunday's presidential and parliamentary elections."I accept the results of the election," he told reporters.As he stepped aside, he had a message for the victor: "Be everyone's president, embrace everyone. That's what I would have done if I had won."Mr Ince, who won 30.6% of the presidential vote, warned that Turkey was heading down a path towards autocracy."Turkey has cut off its links with democracy. It has cut off links with the parliamentary system. It is transitioning toward a one-man regime," the 54-year-old said.The election coincides with the implementation of a new executive presidential system which was approved in a referendum last year. Under the new rules, the office of the prime minister is removed and executive powers are transferred to the president.Voter turnout was high, with 86% of the 56 million eligible voters heading to the polls on Sunday.Rumours that the vote had been rigged were spread by critics, who suggest that voter fraud and intimidation has taken place.Mr Ince had previously complained that unequal campaign conditions in Turkey mean the election was "unjust".Mr Putin told Mr Erdogan that the results of the election were a testament to his political authority and the broad support for his leadership, according to the Kremlin.Kosovo President Hashim Thaci also congratulated Mr Erdogan in a tweet, adding: "Looking forward to our continued good cooperation."Not all messages to the man who has led Turkey for 15 years were as warm.Luxembourg's foreign minister said Mr Erdogan is now "all-powerful" and it will be up to him whether Turkey's relations with the European Union improve.He said: "Mr Erdogan is now an all-powerful man, not just de facto but also formally."

title: why panama is partying like theyve won the cup
story: Panama scored once in the 78th minute - their first-ever World Cup goal - and they're partying like they've walked away with the trophy."How d'you like the way we're celebrating?" I was asked by one fan waving a camera in my face. Terrific. This is carnival, a Panamian fiesta, the greatest show on earth.They're not going to let the matter of almost total annihilation on the pitch get to them. England fans are outnumbered by the Panamians but there are more here than there were in Volgograd.And what a game to watch - Gareth Southgate's young and approachable team now firmly anchored in the hearts of the nation. They looked in control, they looked like they were enjoying themselves, it looked like they had a plan.Long may it last.And, once again, almost in chorus, every fan will tell you what a warm, enthusiastic, astonishing welcome they've had from the Russians."We cannot thank the Russians enough," said Paul Conroy from Liverpool."Boris Johnson doesn't know what he's talking about." In contrast to other nations here, England fans have tried for the main to keep a low profile.Lots say they now regret not bringing their families or encouraging more of their friends to travel.They say the government did little more than scaremonger ahead of the games. I ask Mr Conroy if he has a message for Russia's president, given his enthusiasm for the country's people."Politics is a different thing," he says."This is a festival of football, for ordinary people." This World Cup is going terrifically well for England, for the Russian national team and therefore by default for the Russian president too.

title: world cup subplots when football meets global politics
story: Two Switzerland players became the subject of a FIFA investigation for their controversial goal celebrations in the team's 2-1 win against Serbia.Granit Xhaka and Xherdan Shaqiri both made apparent Albanian nationalist gestures which imitate the Albanian flag.The pair have ethnic Albanian heritage with Kosovan roots.Many people in the former Serbian province of Kosovo, which has an ethnic Albanian majority, identify with the red and black flag.A Serbian crackdown on Kosovo Albanian rebels in 1998-1999 only ended when NATO intervened.Kosovo declared independence in 2008 but Serbia does not recognise the status, and relations between the two countries remain tense.Serbian media called Shaqiri's goal gesture "shameful provocation".Shaqiri was born in Kosovo, while Xhaka's parents are originally from Kosovo.His brother plays for Albania's national team.Mo Salah's honorary citizenship Liverpool's Egyptian forward has been urged to explain his decision to accept an honorary citizenship of Chechnya by its ruler Ramzan Kadyrov.Mr Kadyrov has been widely criticised for a series of human rights violations.Salah was given the decree at a dinner in honour of the Egypt team ahead of their departure for Volgograd.Liverpool fan group Kop Outs, which represents the LGBT community, and LGBT fan group alliance Pride In Football, said in a joint statement that players must set standards of behaviour."We demand urgent dialogue with Mo and FIFA to explain how untenable this is," they said. "We demand an apology from the Egyptian FA for the flagrant disregard of the torture that is currently happening in Chechnya."Sweden's Jimmy Durmaz condemned racist abuse he received after the country's 2-1 loss to Germany.Durmaz, born in Sweden to Assyrian parents who emigrated from Turkey, has been abused since he gave away a free-kick that led to Germany's winning goal.In a statement read in front of cameras, he said: "I am Swedish and I am proud to play in the Swedish national team. That's the biggest thing you can do as a football player."I will never let any racists destroy that pride. We must all stand against all forms of racism."Iranian women finally allowed to enjoy football Iranian women have not been allowed to attend football stadiums to watch men play football in years past.However, in their country's clash against Spain, a ban was lifted allowing Iranian women to go to a football stadium for the first time since the Islamic Revolution in 1979.The Prince/Putin handshake When Russia opened the scoring against Saudi Arabia in the World Cup opener, the focus quickly moved from the first goal of the tournament to the two most prominent spectators.Saudi King Salman and Russian President Vladimir Putin exchanged a friendly handshake after Yury Gazinsky netted for Russia after just 12 minutes.The pair continued to share handshakes and exchanges as Russia went on to win 5-0.King Salman and Mr Putin support opposing sides in the Syrian civil war that has killed more than half a million people.Russia backs Syrian President Bashar al Assad while Saudi Arabia supports Syrian rebels.However, Moscow and Riyadh have a common ground in that they are both global oil superpowers and dominate the world's crude oil production.LGBT flag confiscations An England fan has spoken of his frustration after he was told to take a rainbow flag down inside Nizhny Novgorod stadium.England fan Joe White said a steward removed his Three Lions Pride St George's Cross before England's 6-1 win over Panama.

title: ghosts britains past loom over
story: NewsopinionWhy the ghosts of Britain's past will loom over Prince William's visit to IsraelThe Duke of Cambridge is making the first official royal visit to Israel since it was founded and, in the process, entering a diplomatic mine field&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics15:37, 25 JUN 2018Updated15:53, 25 JUN 2018NewsopinionPrince William arrives in Jordan on the first day of his Middle East tour (Image: Daily Mirror)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen Prince William arrives in Israel tonight history will weigh heavily on his shoulders.  The future king is visiting a country founded in the dying days of the British Empire and where the ghosts of our shared past still loom large.  This is the first official visit by a member of the Royal Family to the state of Israel since it was founded 70 years’ ago. Prince Charles has been to Israel for the funerals of the former prime minister Yitzhak Rabin and the late president Shimon Peres but until this week the Palace and the Foreign Office had rejected multiple invitations by the Israeli Government for an official trip. Prince William’s itinerary has been meticulously planned to avoid, as far as possible, any diplomatic controversy.  His five-day tour of the Middle East began in Jordan and will end in Palestine to emphasis the visit is politically neutral. Meetings with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and President Reuven Rivlin have been carefully balanced by an audience with Palestinian Authority President Mahmoud Abbas when the Prince travels to Ramallah. Yet William cannot escape either Britain’s past or Israel’s troubled history since its foundation. Tonight he will stay in the King David Hotel in Jerusalem where in 1946 Zionist insurgents fighting for independence killed dozens of British soldiers charged with maintaining peace in the protectorate. When the UK agreed to hand over control of the region to the United Nations two years' later there was resentment that we were more interested in protecting our interests in neighbouring Arab countries than helping the founding of Israel. The fact that the British royal family has made frequent visits to Saudi Arabia in the intervening years has done little to change this perception among Israelis.

title: how theresa tried airbrush out
story: NewsHow Theresa May tried to airbrush out her opposition to a third runway at Heathrow AirportThe PM made an audacious bid to wipe her long-lived bias from the internet. But the internet never forgets&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporterMikey SmithPolitical reporter13:12, 25 JUN 2018Updated13:13, 25 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May faces a crunch vote on Heathrow airport expansion today, as she orders her MPs to back plans for a third runway.  The Prime Minister is so strongly behind the plan to grow Britain's biggest air transit hub, one of her ministers, Greg Hands , has already quit the government in order to vote against it.  And Boris Johnson is currently in an unspecified foreign nation, in a conveniently timed overseas trip, so the famously anti-expansion Foreign Secretary can hold on to his job without having to go back on his promises. But Theresa May hasn't always been a big fan of Heathrow Airport expansion. In fact, before she was Prime Minister, she was staunchly against the idea. The PM - whose Maidenhead seat is in Heathrow Airport's flight path - made an audacious bid to wipe her long-lived bias from history. But it was on the internet and, of course, the internet never forgets.  A simple check using archive tools shows how a string of critical statements were unceremoniously deleted from her constituency website.  She said locals would be devastated by a third runway and there were no planes currently on the market that would meet green targets. She added in the 16 January 2009 post: A third runway will result in thousands of additional flights, increased noise and more pollution for thousands of people. We need a better Heathrow, not a bigger Heathrow.” So her view was clear and the post was still up on the site as late as May 2015. But after that, it mysteriously disappeared - and now brings up a 'not found' error message.  It's not a one-off either. In March 2008 she warned the evasive government had already made up its mind on expanding Heathrow. But some time before January 2016, that too was deleted.  What does the PM say about changing her tune on Heathrow? The Prime Minister's spokesman said today: I think the PM has set out on a number of occasions why she believes expanding Heathrow is the right decision for Britain. She thinks it sends out an important message about global Britain and making the most of the opportunities that lie ahead of us.” Asked if Mrs MAy still thinks her constituents will be ‘devastated’ by a third runway? “As I say you can look to the Prime Minister’s various comments on why it is the right decision to take.

title: mps not vote important issues
story: NewsWhy do some MPs not vote on important issues?If you're wondering why your MP didn't vote - or was required to vote a particular way - there may be a procedural reason for it&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter16:00, 25 JUN 2018News (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPeople are increasingly taking an interest in how their MP votes on crucial votes in the House of Commons. And these days Commons authorities release the information digitally, allowing us to provide readers searchable widgets. But Parliamentary procedures can be confusing. Your MP may be down as not having voted - or having voted a particular way - because of Commons convention. And an MP not voting doesn't necessarily mean they have abstained - a deliberate choice to withhold their vote. Here's a round up of the reasons your MP might not have voted.  The Speaker of the House of Commons and his or her deputies are members of political parties. But while they remain MPs after taking the chair, they don't vote in the Commons - unless there is a tie, in which case they have a casting vote. If they're a 'teller'  For every commons vote, four MPs act as 'tellers'. They're the people who physically count the number of MPs walking through the voting lobbies. Tellers aren't counted towards the vote totals, but that doesn't mean the tellers have abstained. In fact, the tellers are often enthusiastically for or against a motion - which is why they choose to be tellers. For the purposes of our widgets, we list tellers as having voted according to which lobby they are counting.

title: tory mutiny erupts over brexit
story: NewsTory mutiny erupts over Brexit as minister deals vicious slapdown to Jeremy Hunt and Boris JohnsonDefence Minister Guto Bebb lashed out at 'inflammatory' Tories for attacking business - while Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom rebuked Theresa May's customs plan&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter15:18, 25 JUN 2018Updated15:48, 25 JUN 2018NewsTheresa May's Tory Cabinet are fighting over Brexit (Image: REUTERS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTory wounds have reopened over Brexit after members of Theresa May's top team clashed viciously in public. Defence Minister Guto Bebb lashed out at 'inflammatory' Tories for attacking business - while Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom rebuked Theresa May's customs plan. Firstly Mr Bebb criticised Tories who had turned on firms for warning about the impact of Brexit. Jeremy Hunt said Airbus was completely inappropriate for threatening to leave the UK. And Boris Johnson reportedly said f*** business! at a reception. But Mr Bebb told the BBC: The dismissive attitudes shown towards our business community by senior Cabinet ministers is both unworthy and inflammatory.”  Mr Bebb added: Do the leadership aspirations of multi-millionaires trump the need to listen to the employers and employees of this country?” Both Boris Johnson and Jeremy Hunt are millionaires - and both have held ambitions for leadership. Business Secretary Greg Clark sided with Mr Bebb today, telling MPs Airbus was entitled to be listened to with respect. Downing Street was forced to defend its position today amid the row. Asked about Jeremy Hunt's comments, Theresa May's spokesman said: If individual companies or others choose to make their views public, that is up to them.   But he refused to comment on Boris Johnson's alleged remarks, saying: Well look, I don't see what I can usefully add on some sort of alleged anonymous briefing of a remark that may or may not have been made. I think the fact we've had 2,500 meeting would suggest to you we're engaging with business.  Meanwhile fresh splits opened at Cabinet level as a minister publicly shot down one of Theresa May's two options for customs after Brexit. Andrea Leadsom, the Leader of the Commons, claimed the PM's preferred model of a customs partnership was bureaucratic, unwieldy and impractical. She added: The problem with complications, particularly for businesses, they are not keen on more bureaucracy, more red tape. That is potentially a less attractive option for businesses themselves. Instead she urged the PM to pick the Brexiteers' favoured 'Max Fac' option - even though civil servants have warned it could cost &pound20billion a year. Asked about Ms Leadsom's criticism, No10 insisted the 'customs partnership' remained on the table. But the Prime Minister's spokesman admitted: More work needed to be done in relation to that model. That work is being conducted by a working group. More work is being done on both options. That remains the position. The EU has as a customs union. This means the 28 member states trade EU goods for free - and set an equal tariff on non-EU goods. For example, US car imports to the EU carry a 10% tariff. Being in the customs union benefits the UK, because the EU is our largest trading partner and it prevents lorry checks at the border. But Theresa May wants the UK to leave the customs union because otherwise, Britain will have to follow EU rules and cannot strike trade deals around the world. She is considering two options. Customs partnership: This would see Britain collect tariffs on all imports on behalf of the EU. If the UK tariff is lower than the EU one, then firms would be able to reclaim the difference. Maximum Facilitation - 'Max Fac': This would use high-tech tracking devices to monitor the flow of goods. Businesses would operate as “trusted traders” and would be able to pay any tariffs at regular intervals rather than every time they cross a border.

story: Advertorial11 best spots in the UK to watch an amazing sunset this summerThis week marks the summer solstice – and is also the official start of summer. So what better time to explore the UK and take in some of the country’s most breathtaking bike rides?&nbspShareByHolly Thatcher14:24, 22 JUN 2018Updated21:07, 23 JUN 2018Advertorial (Image: Getty)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe've been blessed with some decent weather already in 2018 - but this week is when summer *officially* begins. June 21, the summer solstice in the Northern Hemisphere, is the longest day in the year - affording us approximately 17 hours of daylight. Technically, this also means that the nights will start drawing in again now - so there's really no time like the present to get out and explore the great outdoors on some of the country’s most breathtaking bike rides. We've taken a look around the UK to find the best places to watch the sun setting. 1. Museum of Scottish Lighthouses, Fraserburgh, Scotland  A small village called Maud in Aberdeenshire offers a starting place for a traffic-free cycle to the coast. If you're in the mood to learn then head to the Museum of Scottish Lighthouses in Fraserburgh. The sun will set at around 10.12pm this week in this part of Scotland, so you've got loads of time to enjoy the start of the summer. Bike need replacing?   If your existing bike needs replacing, you'll want something efficient and speedy for the roads - like the Carrera Parva Hybrid bike , which comes in versions for both men and women and is now just &pound210 (a saving of &pound90). And if you don't need a new bike, why not have yours checked over before setting off. Like any mode of transport your bike needs to be looked after and regularly checked for wear and tear. Halfords offers a 32-point Free Bike Check which includes:  Frame, saddle and handlebar Wheels including tyres, rims, spokes and hubs Brake system including levers, calipers, pads and cables / hoses Drivetrain including gears, levers, chain, bottom bracket, cranks and cables  2. The Eden Project, Cornwall   Why not spend the day enjoying the amazing sights at the Eden Project? Best of all, if you arrive by bike you'll get a discount on entry. Pentewan Sands is also nearby and boasts amazing family facilities - as well as the nearby Pentewan Cycle Trail. For additional comfort pack an Urban Escape Folding Table And Bench Set , &pound40 (was &pound50, save &pound10) which folds down into a single carry case to make it easy to transport and store.  3. Pembrokeshire Coast National Park, Wales  The Pembrokeshire Coast Path is an absolutely beautiful part of Wales and a stunning place to watch the sun go down. There are loads of campsites in the area, including some unique places to stay. There are plenty of bike routes too, with some offering traffic-free options if you want a more peaceful ride. In Pembrokeshire you can expect the sun to set around 9:39pm. Why not try..   The Boardman ADV 8.8 Adventure Bike , &pound750, is a bike truly made to help you explore new possibilities. If you're packing up the whole family into the car for a camping trip, make sure it's in good running order first. A Free Car Check performed by Halfords experts will put your mind at rest. Book online or just pop in to your local Halfords store and trained colleagues will carry out a free car bulb check and check your battery, wiper blades, engine oil level and air conditioning, and check for any windscreen chips. Edinburgh Castle, Scotland  There are few places that are as stunning as Edinburgh Castle, located atop Castle Rock. title: dont panic remember youre british
story: News“Don't panic! Remember, you're British!”: One of the last known survivors of HMS Spartan recalls moment German bomb sunk British warshipEXCLUSIVE: Five officers and 41 enlisted men were posted killed or missing presumed killed, and 42 enlisted men were wounded after the bombing on January 29, 1944.&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDrew Tapley12:44, 25 JUN 2018NewsDouglas was stationed at his gun placement on an upper deck of the anchored Spartan, preparing to bombard German ramparts along the beachhead (Image: Drew Tapley)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email“Don't panic! Remember, you're British!”, screamed the officer to HMS Spartan gunner Ron Douglas as a massive German bomb ripped into the British warship. The Luftwaffe had just launched an anti-shipping glide bomb attack on the fleet, with radio-controlled missiles and the ship was sinking fast. But when the order was made to abandon ship, there was one problem for 18-year Ron...he couldn’t swim. Now 93, Ron was one of the lucky ones and is believed to be one of the last known survivors of HMS Spartan. Five officers and 41 enlisted men were posted killed or missing presumed killed, and 42 enlisted men were wounded after the bombing on January 29, 1944, during World War II.  Memories of that awful night still haunt Ron and he has barely spoken about it until now. Fresh from a naval training base in Portsmouth in late 1943, Douglas had never seen live action before. Sitting in his room, legs crossed with a cup of tea in his hand, he recalls the day in 1943 when his conscription papers arrived at his home in Glasgow, Scotland. “My mother came to see me one day, crying. She said, ‘It’s your papers. You've got to go to Portsmouth’. I said, ‘Where's that?’ and she told me it’s over 400 miles away, and that I needed to report to the barracks there.” At that time, the apprentice plumber had never been farther than a mile from his home. “They put me on a train to London with my conscription papers. I was scared as hell.” Douglas commuted straight to Portsmouth to start his basic training as a naval gunner.  “They called all the new recruits into a room, and a senior officer told us, ‘You're now in the British Royal Navy. You may have broken your mother's heart, but you won't break mine. I'm your mother now.’ That's how they spoke to you,” said Douglas. A few months later, he was issued assignment papers and instructed to board the HMS Spartan, a brand new Dido-class light cruiser warship that had been commissioned only six months before Douglas stepped foot on it. The Spartan left Portsmouth and made several stops in the Mediterranean prior to anchoring in Anzio Bay, Italy, to provide anti-aircraft support. Douglas knew he was going to Italy because the Germans were there. But that’s about all he knew. When the Spartan arrived, it joined a group of battlecruisers in Operation Single as part of the Battle of Anzio. It was around 7pm on January 29, 1944, and the sun had just gone down.   Outrage as Kensington Palace's &pound24million mega-basement plans approved despite 'flouting council rules'  Douglas was stationed at his gun placement on an upper deck of the anchored Spartan, preparing to bombard German ramparts along the beachhead. Our ships started coming in closer together in the bay, and I knew something was up. Then the air-raid siren went off on one of our destroyers, and all guns pointed to the sky.” He looked up to see two squadrons of German fighter planes coming right at them in a V-shape formation. They were part of the German Luftwaffe, and the first enemy aircraft Douglas had ever seen. “They sounded like a hornet's nest,” recalls Douglas. “My guns had ammunition belts and were ready to go. I’d never seen action before, and I'm sitting there gung-ho but scared out of my mind. My ranking officer announced, ‘Enemy aircraft approaching from the south. Guns at the ready. Await order to fire.’” As Douglas awaited the order, he could see rows of bullets puncturing the surface of the Mediterranean Sea like a flame racing through gasoline. The Luftwaffe was launching an anti-shipping glide bomb attack on the fleet, with radio-controlled missiles released at a distance and guided towards their target via a remote-controlled rocket engine.  “Hold it..,” commanded the officer before adding a sentence that Douglas has replayed in his mind ever since. “Don't panic! Remember, you're British,” said the officer with a voice as calm as brushed velvet. “Don't panic?” balked Douglas at the memory of it. “I’m 18, sitting in an elevated gun placement on a battleship with 0.5-inch machine guns in a four-gun mounting, and I’m watching German fighter planes getting closer and closer—firing at us. They had armour-piercing bullets that could tear up our deck. “When we got the order to return fire, all hell broke loose. I'm shooting and the sight on my gun is vibrating like crazy. I couldn't see if I hit any of the planes as they were travelling at 400 miles an hour.” When the Spartan shook from bow to stern, Douglas knew they had been hit. “I smelt smoke, and the captain announced that we'd been hit in the bulkhead and had a large hole in the side of the ship. ‘Don't panic,’ said the ranking officer again. ‘Remember, you’re British!’ “I didn’t know that the ship was sinking. I just knew that it had been hit. They get hit all the time. But when there's a hole below the waterline, it's definitely time to panic. There were people running all over the place.” The Spartan had received a direct hit to its boiler room from a radio-controlled Henschel Hs 293 monoplane bomb, travelling at about 200 metres a second. After an hour of failed attempts to distinguish the fire, a general order was given to abandon ship. Unfortunately for Douglas, he was not part of that order. “I took this to mean get off the ship as fast as I could, said Douglas, Because it could explode with the munitions on board. But I was manning machine guns, and told to stay put and keep firing.”  Romford killing: Friends of boy, 15, stabbed to death at birthday party heard screaming and crying 'he's dead, he's dead'   The Spartan was taking on water fast, which extinguished the fire but caused it to start listing on one side. Douglas donned a lifejacket and continued to man his post. But when the ship started to roll over, he knew there would soon be a point where it would be too late to jump off. “It was very dark, and other people were already in the water, yet I was ordered to keep firing. You can't abandon your post. The officers in the British Navy were very strict. If you left your post and created danger, they could shoot you.” But the ship was sinking, and all around him people were leaping off the side into the sea. “Once the ship goes down, you don't have much chance. I said to my mate beside me, ‘If he doesn't give the order, I'm emptying this ammunition and getting off’. He said, ‘Me too, Scottie. I'll jump with you’.” Thankfully, it didn’t come down to them being shot on duty after surviving a sinking ship. But when the officer gave the order for his evacuation, Douglas remembered one striking fact. He couldn’t swim. “I told the officer, and he replied, ‘I don't care. Jump!’” His gun placement was as high as a three-story building, and as he looked down at the rolling waves below he knew he would almost certainly die if he stayed onboard. So he jumped. When he entered the water, his first thought was of his mother. “I thought I was going to die, and was thinking about my mother and if I would ever see her again. The waves were rolling and the water was ice cold. There were guys all around me screaming for help, but I was trying to save my own life and didn't want to drown.” His lifejacket kept him afloat as the waves pulled him far enough away from the sinking Spartan to avoid being sucked down with it. Now he had to survive the freezing cold and huge waves that dragged him around in the pitch black winter’s night. As events played out, this may have saved his life from the German planes circulating overhead and firing at the men in the water. “There was another guy not far from me, and we held onto each other. I didn’t want him to die either. He said to me, ‘I'm not going to make it, Jock.’ He was crying. Many guys were crying. I told him, “You'll be alright. We'll get home to Blighty, don't worry.’” “But the waves were getting bigger, and we were going up and down. I was so frightened, and shaking like a leaf. I told him that his mother would be coming to meet him at the barracks. It was just my attempt to cheer him up because mothers don't go near the barracks.” “The waves were rolling so high that I could see one moment and not the next. I was soaking wet, freezing cold and frightened I was going to die.” As he awaited rescue with fellow shipmates, some of whom were injured, the bodies of men who had drowned or been shot or killed in the blast were floating among them. At one point, he looked over at the Spartan as it was turning over, and saw a few people still onboard. After an hour in the water, Douglas started to doubt whether anyone was coming for them. “I didn’t know if we were going to get rescued. I had this little light on my lifejacket, and could see other little lights bobbing up and down in the water.” When he saw a rowing boat coming around to pick the men out of the sea, he starting trying to get to it. “We did the doggy paddle, but it was enough. They pulled me out by my shoulder and my hair—anything to get a grip on me. But it saved my life because some guys never came out at all. They picked out bodies that were floating in the water, but some of them had just sunk.” When he climbed aboard the rescue cruiser, he took a hot shower and was given new clothes and later taken back to the barracks at Portsmouth, debriefed and told he would be getting survivors leave. “I went home to my mother, and she asked, ‘What are you doing here?’ because I'd recently had leave a few months earlier. She knew you didn't just get leave like that in the forces. So I told her they had given us all special leave. I never told her the truth, and she only found that out from my older brother after the war.” Douglas was glad to get back to his mother in Glasgow, but was soon plagued by nightmares of his ordeal. “Sometimes I would wake up and wonder where I was. My mother would say, ‘You're at home, and you're not going back. I'll stop them from taking you back. She didn't even want me to leave the house, but I had to go back or the Navy Police would throw me in the slammer.” Both of his older brothers served in the Royal Navy, and during national service he didn’t see either of them for four years because they had leave at different times. “My mother later asked me why I didn't tell her the truth, and I said that I was afraid she would have given me hell for being on a sunken ship. Honestly, that's what she was like.”  The following year, Douglas joined the Pacific fleet for the war campaign in Japan. Medical officers vaccinated him for tropical diseases like malaria and beriberi, but did not inform him or the other sailors where they were going. All he knew was that their destination was a central depot in Australia, which would be a jumping-off point for someplace hot and belligerent. There were other sailors onboard who had survived Spartan, but he never once held a conversation with any of them about their ordeal. “I was terrified to get back on a warship again, but we never spoke about it to each other,” he shared. As he was heading to Australia on new assignment, the war came to an end, and Douglas was demobilized and returned to Scotland. He emigrated to Canada in 1954, and soon afterwards met his English-born wife, Edith. They had two children, and he went on to become a trades superintendent with Honeywell. This year, the couple will celebrate 63 years of marriage, and both currently reside at Rockcliffe Care Community in Toronto, which is owned by Sienna Senior Living.  More than seven decades have passed since that day, and Douglas has barely spoken about his time during the war. “My wife knows I was in the navy, but I never spoke much about the war. I don't talk about it. She didn't know me when I was a sailor, and found out later during the course of conversation that I was on the Spartan.”

story: NewsEngland World Cup fan gets racist hate mail for putting up St George flagsWARNING OFFENSIVE CONTENT: The 31-year-old Sikh business owner defiantly bought four more flags after the vile letter arrived in the post&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByRosaleen Fenton13:21, 25 JUN 2018Updated13:55, 25 JUN 2018NewsThe anonymous letter was sent after two flags went up at GMS Heating &amp Plumbing (Image: GMS Heating &amp Plumbing)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A Sikh supporter of England's World Cup team has received racist hate mail after hanging two St George flags in his shop.  The vile letter sent to business owner Gagan, 31, claims he put up the wrong flags and he should not show support for England due to the colour of his skin. It arrived in the post just one day after the manager of GMS Heating &amp Plumbing raised the flag at his store in Ilford, east London, last Wednesday. The defiant business owner said his father immediately went out to purchase four more flags after opening the poison pen letter, which was posted anonymously.  Littered with spelling mistakes and bad grammar, the letter, addressed Dear uncle, said: You have put [the] wrong flag outside your shop when you have come from Indian. Have you forgot your skin colour? It went on to say: You should put the Pakistan flag outside your shop not British.    If National Front skinheads saw this flag outside they will kick you back to India without your trousers on. Gagan said the family business always puts out St George flags for major sporting events. He has refused to back down after receiving the letter. He said: We're just trying to have some fun and people want to ruin it by saying it shouldn't be done. It should be done.

title: family four traumatised masked gang
story: NewsFamily-of-four traumatised as masked gang attack their home with baseball batsAt least eight men in balaclavas smashed the windows and doors of a family home in Plymouth, Devon, leaving Amy Stevens, her partner and two children cowering in fear for their lives&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByWilliam Telford07:52, 25 JUN 2018NewsAmy Stevens with Lee Jeffrey, whose quick-thinking stopped the gang from entering the flat (Image: Plymouth Herald WS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family were left in fear for their lives when a gang of masked men attacked their home with baseball bats. Mum-of-two Amy Stevens said they thought they were going to die and her children were petrified following the horrendous incident.  Amy and partner Lee Jeffrey have no idea why around eight balaclava-clad men should target their  property in Whitleigh, Plymouth, which left children Shanella, aged 11, and Amelia, aged seven, traumatised.   It is believed there was also damage caused to the home of a 96-year-old neighbour during the incident, Plymouth Live reports.   The couple now have a repair bill of more than &pound1,000 but say that pales when they think of what could have happened to their children. Shanella had not long left the bathroom when the window was smashed, showering the room with glass. And if Lee, 33, had not locked the front door of the couple’s flat when he saw the men approaching, the couple fear they could have come inside and caused mayhem. “You can fix a window, but if Lee had not been able to lock the front door in time and my daughter had still been in the bathroom I dread to think what would have happened,” said 31-year-old Amy.  “It was awful, the children are shaking every time there is a knock at the door now, but, to be honest, I am too.” Police are investigating the incident but have yet to identify the men involved or the vehicle they escaped in. They are also trying to work out the motive for the attack. The incident happened in the same street where police are still investigating the cause of a blaze which damaged two cars on June 1. Arson has hot been ruled out.  Amy and Lee have no connection to that incident and are mystified as to why anyone should want to attack their property or the family. The drama unfolded at about 11pm on June 23, when Lee was watching TV in the front room of the ground-floor, two-bedroom flat. “He was on the sofa and heard a massive banging and shouting outside,” said Amy. “He looked out and saw about eight men in balaclavas and rushed to lock the front door.  “Then the men started batting hell out of the windows. The smashed all of them.” She said the front door window, another window and all the panes in the bathroom window were smashed. “It was like something you would see on Crimewatch. “They have caused about &pound1,000 of damage.” Police reacted quickly to the incident as soon as the family rang in.

title: kate middleton could new title
story: NewsKate Middleton could get a new title when the Queen dies - and it will be extremely specialPrince William will get a brand new title when the Queen passes away, and there's a good chance Kate Middleton will take it too&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience Writer14:19, 25 JUN 2018Updated14:20, 25 JUN 2018NewsKate Middleton is the Duchess of Cambridge at the moment, but this could all chance (Image: Getty Images Europe)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen she married her prince back on 2011 Kate Middleton became the Duchess of Cambridge. Along with Prince William, the couple have been known by their official titles ever since, and their children George, Charlotte and Louis have also taken on their title.  But like many other things in the royal family, this will change when the Queen dies .  William and Kate will get new titles to represent them moving up the line of succession.  At the moment, Prince Charles is the Prince of Wales. This title isn't just his, it's the title which is traditionally given to the heir to the throne and Charles is the 21st man to be given it. Diana became the Princess of Wales after she married Charles in 1981. Technically, Camilla should now have the title but she turned it down out of respect for Diana. But after the Queen's death and Prince Charles becomes king, Prince William will become the Prince of Wales and Kate will probably be offered the title of Princess of Wales.  It probably wouldn't have gone down well with the public if Camilla took the title, but it's a very different situation with Kate. She might decide she wants to use the name as a tribute to the mother-in-law she never met. Until Wills, Prince Harry won't get a new title when his grandmother dies as he is much further down the line of succession.  When he married Meghan Markle earlier this year, the Queen gave them the titles the Duke and Duchess of Sussex.  Even though the Duke title has been used before, Meghan is the first Duchess of Sussex because of a rather upsetting course of events surrounding the original.  The original was Prince Augustus Frederick, the son of George III born in 1773. He was university educated and campaigned for the abolition of slavery.

title: more 80 chihuahuas found house
story: NewsMore than 80 chihuahuas found in house that 'looked like it had been hit by an earthquake'RSPCA staff at Newbrook Farm Animal Hospital worked through the night to treat all the dogs&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByElaine McCahill16:06, 25 JUN 2018NewsPolice were shocked to find 82 chihuahuas crammed into a house while investigating a woman's death (Image: SWNS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMore than 80 chihuahuas were found crammed inside a woman's home in squalid conditions by police investigating her death. The RSPCA were called to assist officers who were probing the unexplained death of a woman in April last year. The animal charity were first told there were around 30 dogs - but when inspectors arrived they were shocked find a staggering 82 chihuahuas inside. The pooches filled every corner of the filthy and cramped house in Birmingham - including behind kitchen appliances, and had matted coats, fleas and burns.  The dogs were believed to have descended from just one couple - Blue and Tinkerbell - four years ago. As a result of inbreeding, some had serious behavioural issues and were extremely aggressive and unhappy. RSPCA inspector Herchy Boal said: “The officers asked us for help with around 30 dogs but I was busy dealing with another emergency elsewhere. “When they called me again a few hours later they were extremely concerned about the conditions they had found the dogs in, claiming they believed there were actually in excess of 40 small breeds. “When I arrived at the property I found 82 dogs inside.  They literally started appearing from everywhere. We would move the washing machine and suddenly there’d be six faces looking at you. It was incredible where they were able to hide. “The house looked like an earthquake had hit it, everything was higgledy piggledy, it was really chaotic and dirty. “We called out a vet who said the house was too hazardous and the dogs couldn’t stay there, it was filthy and cramped. They were all hiding - barking and snapping at us.” West Midlands Police had launched an investigation after a woman who lived at the property died.  But following their enquiries, they established that there were no suspicious circumstances and that she had died from complications after an accident. All 82 dogs were removed and taken to the charity’s Newbrook Farm Animal Hospital in Birmingham. Staff worked through the night to check over all of the dogs and ensure they received necessary treatment. Inspector Boal said: “We didn’t finish work until 11am the next day. “The woman and her husband, Stephen, had started out with two pet chihuahuas - Blue and Tinkerbell. Unfortunately, they didn’t get their dogs neutered and four years later, they had 82 dogs.  “This was a classic hoarding situation but it was clear the couple had loved their dogs and things had simply got out of hand. “We worked with Stephen to renovate and clean the home while we cared for the dogs. We returned four of the dogs to him and re-homed the rest. “Two of the dogs that went back to Stephen had serious behavioural issues and were extremely aggressive and unhappy. But when we returned them to him they were like different dogs and were so much happier. “This was a really sad case but it was also a really memorable one for me due to the sheer number of dogs involved.  “I really hope we can use this story to make it clear why it’s so important to neuter your pets not only to avoid unwanted litters but also to avoid inbreeding which can result in serious health and behaviour problems in puppies. Multiple dog households are very challenging, and with this job, I had no idea how many dogs I was taking out. They literally started appearing from absolutely everywhere. We'd move the washing machine and suddenly there would be six faces looking at you and it was just incredible where they were able to hide.

title: mums horror home oven cleaner
story: NewsMum's horror as home oven cleaner burns two-year-old leaving him looking like 'acid attack' victimAaron Cadder was playing in his grandmothers kitchen when a corrosive household item left him with third-degree burns&nbspShareByNicola MoorsBronwen Weatherby15:23, 25 JUN 2018Updated15:25, 25 JUN 2018NewsAaron had to undergo surgery to skin graft his leg (Image: HotSpot Media)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA horrified mum has issued a warning to parents after her son was left looking like an acid attack victim by household oven cleaner.  Toddler Aaron Cadder was playing in his grandmother's kitchen when he got hold of the dangerous product and spilt it on his legs, reported the Daily Record.  The corrosive liquid - which is available to buy at supermarkets - soaked through the two-year-old's trousers causing him to suffer serious burns and a frightening allergic reaction. Mum Paula said when she first saw Aaron in hospital it looked like his face had melted and thought his little one would be left blind.  Paula, 25, from Glasgow , said: “He was in so much pain and never left my side afterwards.   “He looked like an acid attack victim.      “It’s just unimaginable that such a common household product could do so much damage.   “Thankfully Aaron has made a full recovery but he has been left scarred for life.”   Paula, who also has a daughter Kelsey, seven, says her partner Peter, 28, a construction worker, took Aaron for a haircut before heading over to his mum’s house in December last year.  Aaron and his gran Margaret, 63, are extremely close and he stays over once a week.  Paula, a full-time mum, said: “Margaret had been cleaning the oven when Peter and Aaron popped round, so she put the bottle back in the cupboard.      “Then she left the room for a couple of seconds to pop some washing on when Aaron came running after her screaming.   “His little face was red and swollen. When she spotted the oven cleaner on the floor, she realised he must have gotten hold of the bottle and ran his face under cold water.   “She called Peter’s sister, who lives up the road and they took Aaron to Glasgow Royal Infirmary , where Peter and I met them.   “During the car journey, Margaret noticed Aaron was grabbing his legs and when she tried to pull his trousers off to look further, they were stuck.   “She discovered the oven cleaner had soaked through to his legs.”        At hospital, doctors sprayed Aaron’s legs and face with water to remove the cleaner.   Later that day, he was transferred by ambulance to the Royal Hospital for Children to receive specialist care.    Paula said: “When I first saw Aaron’s face, I was shocked – it was so red.   “It looked like his face had melted.   “His eyes had swollen to the size of golf balls and he couldn’t open them.   “I immediately thought he’d be left blind but as soon as I walked towards his hospital bed, he shouted ‘Mummy’.   “It was such a relief that he could see.”    Surgeons took Aaron into theatre where he was given a general anaesthetic so they could remove the dead skin and bandage him up.   Doctors revealed he’d suffered a third-degree burn on his left leg which stretched from his ankle to his groin, and he needed skin grafts to repair the damage.   Thankfully Aaron’s face wasn’t burnt by the cleaner – instead, he’d suffered an allergic reaction which doctors prescribed antibiotics and eye drops for.   And three days after the accident, the little tot underwent two skin grafts in a two-hour operation on his legs.   Paula says: “It was awful, I felt constantly sick with worry and couldn’t stop crying.   “After his operation, Aaron was forced to wear a half cast on his leg so he couldn’t bend it and undo the skin graft.”      After a week in hospital, Aaron was discharged just two days before Christmas day.   Paula said: “He was forced to sit still instead of playing with his toys.”   Eight days later, Aaron’s cast was removed and doctors were pleased with his progress.   Paula says: “Doctors told me he would be left scarred and gave me gel to reduce the redness.   “I’m just thankful that they’re on his leg and are easily covered up.  He’ll need more skin grafts in the future as he grows but we’re taking it each day at a time.  Every day I replay receiving that phone call telling me Aaron had been hurt.

title: mystery man who woke up
story: NewsMystery of man who woke up from two-month coma in hospital with no idea how he got thereBrain damaged Jason Fisher, 45, of Hull, East Yorkshire, was found unconscious in the road more than two years ago but still does not know why his life has been changed forever&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByJames CampbellCharlotte Neal11:52, 25 JUN 2018Updated11:53, 25 JUN 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man who woke up from a coma after being found unconscious outside a pub still does not know how he got there two years later.  Now brain damaged after suffering serious injuries, Jason Fisher is none the wiser as to whether he fell, was hit by a car or was attacked, although the 45-year-old thinks the latter is most likely.  He was found outside the Tigers Lair pub, in Hull, East Yorkshire, on January 22, 2016. Ever since he has been attempting to piece together exactly what happened.  Now he has spoken to Hull Live in his search for clues.   “It happened around the time of my birthday, I had not been out on a heavy night but I simply don’t remember anything around that time, he said. In fact from Christmas up until waking up in hospital is a total blank. “Apparently, I was found outside the Tigers Lair. I’m not sure if any CCTV from the time would shed any light on what happened. “I might have had a couple of drinks but I don’t think I would have been on a big night out. I was on my own at the time so family and friends cannot help. “I have no idea whether I was assaulted, fell, was hit by a car or had some kind of aneurysm. My dad thinks the trauma was too great for a fall and it does appear I was attacked.” Having made a significant recovery, Mr Fisher now feels it is time to try and find out what happened. “It is not fair on my girlfriend as I just keep asking what happened, he said.  “It is tormenting me now and I need to try and figure it out. People keep asking me about it and I just have to tell them I have no idea. I lost my phone or it was stolen so I cannot look at texts or phone calls from that time to help me.” Mr Fisher says he knows the lapse in time will make finding answers difficult, but he remains hopeful. He said: “I understand it is a very strange situation and it may seem odd to be asking questions more than two years after it happened, but I have spent time trying to get better and when I try to put what happened aside I can’t. “I am pleading for anyone who knows anything to come forward. I know it was a long time ago but I am desperate for answers. “I just want to know what happened so I can get closure and move forward with my life.  Mr Fisher has worked hard to recover from the devastating brain injury, for which he spent two months in a coma for, but it is a constant battle. He said: “I was in hospital in an induced coma for two months and the first thing I remember was being transferred from Hull Royal Infirmary to Castle Hill’s brain injury unit. “I then concentrated on learning to walk and talk again and managed to do to in a fairly short space of time. “I had a blood clot on the side of my brain and I had lengthy surgery. My right side is not right and it is like I have had a stroke. “I have friends from my time in the brain injury unit who are now confined to a wheelchair so in some ways I feel lucky.” But despite making huge progress he still suffers badly from memory loss and poor motor skills. “My short term memory is completely shot, he said.

story: NewsThe Queen is paying Meghan Markle a huge honour by handing over important new roleThe Duchess of Sussex has clearly made an excellent impression&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZahra MulroySocial Audience Editor13:10, 25 JUN 2018NewsOne has a new job for you (Image: Getty Images Europe)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email She's only been part of the most famous family in the world for a little over a month, but Meghan Markle seems to have cemented her place within it.
